Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: Probably 3 - 4 hours per week. The midterm essay took me around 20 hours, and the final essay/group project took me around 10-15 hours.
5 hours
2-3 hours doing the readings and writing the reflection
4 - 6 hours to read and write a reflection every week

1 on normal weeks doing readings and a one page write up on them
about 7 for final and midterm
2-3 hours when there weren't projects due. Approximately 5-6 hours when there were. However, it was very enjoyable work and I probably spent more time than absolutely necessary on it.
3 hours per week
3 hrs
10-12 hours per week.
Approximately 3 hours per week, though this number would appropriately increase when larger assignments were due.
1-2 hours
4 hours
3-4 hours
I spent about 6 hours a week outside of the classroom doing the assigned readings and constructing the weekly summaries in preparation for class.
2 hours

Strengths- the readings and guest speakers were wonderful

Weaknesses- not a lot of time for group discussion

Strengths- content, guest speakers, passion of Professor
Weaknesses- would love to hear more from the professor

I really liked all of the guest expert speakers as well as the broad variety of topics covered in the course. 
I would have liked more instruction from Professor Cunningham herself, since I think she has a wealth of knowledge to share.

This was a very good class for anyone who was familiar with sexual and reproductive health, and wanted to hear real-life experiences and information from speakers. I really liked the various speakers that we heard from, but some of them felt like they were just trying to pass the time, and there may have been better speakers for specific topics. I also wish we discussed the articles more, I often felt like there wasn't really a point to the readings and reflection if the content wasn't always brought up the next class.

This course surveyed a lot of themes relevant to the fields of Sexual & Reproductive Health. It was a great way to not only explore areas that I already found interesting, but also gain exposure to a variety of new topics. I think it could benefit from more continuity between weeks, as well as more chance for discussion of the readings, but I thoroughly enjoyed the chance to hear from experts each week, some of whom I've been able to keep in contact with.

I did not enjoy that the professor listed as the teacher of the course never lectured; I felt that having only guest lecturers significantly minimized the structure and ability to learn in the class. I strongly think this needs to be corrected and replaced with a true lecture-based structure combined with some high quality guest speakers.
This course was good - I felt that there were too many reading responses in the course.

the professor didn't really teach the class herself, there were always speakers and I think this took away from making the class cohesive from one to the next. It is also too long and the speakers were always passionate to share about their topics (which is great), but it just made it hard to get through the entire class without a break in a timely way. 

-overall, the professor should stay and she should get to teach the class again (as she has brought many great topics to our attention), I just believe the classes structure needs a little reframing

Good class overall, but I really wish we took more time to go over content/material as a class before diving into guest lecturers or other activities, I think it would have been really helpful to learn some more information early on in the course!

Going into this course I was not aware of the structure. There were guest lecturers every class, sometimes more than one, that took up most, if not all, of the class time. The professor rarely "lectured" and there weren't many class discussions outside of questions asked to the guest lecturers. The papers we read throughout the semester were interesting, the weekly papers were too short to allow for critical thinking considering you had to mention each paper and therefore were mostly just a nuisance to prove you read each week. The final group project was also short, requiring just a few pages to be written by each group member, and I don't think we conducive to each of us learning deeply about our assigned topic. I did like the set up the last day of class where we each went around talking for a few minutes to each group- it was a great alternative to sitting through each group present.
This class was just a little disorganized- next year I think it will improve a lot! Very interesting and important topics, so it will likely remain popular.

The course was overall ok.  The guest speakers were very interesting and a cool way to run the class, but I struggled with how the participation component of class was set up.  Many of the topics discussed are controversial, and I do not have much background on them. I feared sounding ignorant making a comment to a guest speaker who was an expert in the topic or in a classroom where many students have a deep understanding of these topics.  Since many students in the room had strong opinions on these topics, it was difficult to speak up when I knew my background was not strong enough to form a solid opinion. We never had lectures to provide background, we would jump right into speakers.  Each week, we were required to do readings and write a write up on them.  After spending all that time reading and writing we rarely actually discussed the readings.  I would have felt much more comfortable discussing the readings rather than raising questions to a guest speaker, as I would have the readings as background to base opinions and questions on.  Having little background on the topic, it was frustrating and intimidating for the only way to gain participation points in the class to be confronting an expert in a topic.  Although I do greatly enjoy guest speakers, if readings are required, they should also be discussed.  The lack of regular class discussion lead the assignments to feel like busy work and not the best use of my time.  Part of our assignment was to ask questions for the speakers, and those were very rarely addressed, especially at the beginning of the semester, again making these assignments feel more like busy work than anything else as nothing ever came of these write ups.

Strengths 

- diversity of speakers 
- engaging content

Weakness 
- limited opportunity to discuss

I really enjoyed this course. It presented a broad introduction to the field of sexual and reproductive health and reproductive justice. The professor was immensely knowledgeable as was the TF, Jaclyn. Furthermore, every week, Dr. C invited speakers (professionals and experts from the New Haven community and Yale) to present on their work in front of the class. The set up of this class was unusual in that way, but I liked that the rhythm of the class was varied by having different topics/different speakers each week.
Enjoyed topics but room for improvement in structure and organization. Since its the first year its offered I expect this to improve in time.

Strength: The course was fantastic! I  loved the guest speakers, the readings were very thought-provoking, the projects were so much fun!
Weakness: I almost wish the class was twice-a-week. I wish we could have had more in-class discussions. I'm also unused to the group paper, so I don't know if I liked it, but I did like hearing what other people said about their projects, so I feel it was the only way to get the breadth that was necessary.

I enjoyed the course and I strongly believe it is necessary to have a course like this one in the YSPH curriculum. I think this course format should be revised to include more primary instruction on concepts and balanced with guest speakers and class discussion. There is so much that can be covered in the course which is why it's so necessary, but I think it would be more beneficial to cover fewer topics and go more in depth.

I was expecting for this class to be more clinical with public health implications. Instead it was about reproductive justice vs reproductive health. The class was run like a seminar and it was too big to have quality discussion. There were too many guest lectures. The class tried to cover too many topics.

It was a good break from quantitative course. I enjoyed the topics discussed and speakers brought into class. Still, the class had a lot of potential to be more discussion based. Although the speakers were interesting, it would've been good to discuss the topic in small groups and have more time to discuss than what was allotted.

Absolutely brilliant!  I don't know why this course wasn't an option in the past but I'm SO HAPPY its a course option now.  It's incredibly insightful, informative, and relatable considering the current day political climate.  It's easily one of the major highlights of my time at YSPH.

I thoroughly enjoyed this class. I enjoyed the wide array of topics explored although sometimes wished the classes could flow together a little bit better. I enjoyed the guest speakers and discussion format. The format for the class would probably be having one guest speaker for the first half and then having the second half of the class be a discussion.

This course was a fantastic introduction/ survey course in sexual and reproductive health that did a great job catering to all levels of knowledge. This class generated great discussion, and allowed students to learn from many experts in the field. Readings were great as well. Many were very timely. I feel that everything about this class helped prepare me for my future as a public health professional.

Course was an interesting overview of some topics in Sexual and Repro Health but was not comprehensive. Professor relied heavily on guest speakers to provide lectures, which was hit or miss. Readings were interesting and light -- weekly assignments to write reading reflections was easy enough.

This was an excellent class that featured a variety of topics on a broad field. I really appreciated the seminar style which invited students to participate in class discussions in a supportive environment. The teacher and teaching fellow were incredibly receptive to feedback and really made the class a great learning environment.

I am SO glad this course was finally offered this year! Such an important topic which has generated a lot of interest at YSPH. The course was well-organized, and the prof and TF were excellent. Sensitive topics were handled well. It was great to have such interesting guest speakers - my only feedback is that it would have been great to have more group work time and lectures from Professor Cunningham.

Strengths -- This class is FANTASTIC. Definitely one of my favorite classes here at YSPH. It is formatted like a seminar, so that every class you're learning about a new topic. The readings are great and give you the opportunity to engage with a variety of topics. 

Weaknesses- I wish we had more time for discussion and time to ask questions to the speakers. Maybe we can set up a lunch before the class/after to speak with them.
Fantastic course. I suggest that students write 4-5 reflections over the course of the semester, instead of one per week. I would have been able to write more meaningful reflections this way.

Strenghts: interesting readings raising challenges and complex issues; great speakers; very engagement format of assignments.
Weakness: jumping between topics, not much time to go in depth in each one.

The guest speakers gave the class a lot of diversity and different things to look forward to.  However, the breadth of what was covered made it sometimes feel like we were not going deep enough into certain topics.

I thoroughly enjoyed this class, it provided a holistic view into many facets of sexual and reproductive health in the United States. I appreciated the course's format of bringing experts in every field to speak about their professions and careers and providing unique perspectives that we usually do not get from our classroom. Our end-of-semester presentation was a little scattered and difficult to display, but the semester as a whole was enormously informative and enjoyable. As someone hoping to delve deeper into the clinical perspective, this class fulfilled that curiosity while also jogging my interest in topics not previously in my realm of understanding.

I loved this class. It was my favorite this semester! I think Shayna and Jaclyn are wonderful and our class as a whole had an awesome dynamic! I loved the different quests we have, the readings and the work was good too. My only critique would be that I would have loved for their to be more internal class discussion about our readings.

I really enjoyed the structure of this course. Our readings were all very interesting and I enjoyed being able to reflect on them in a weekly reading response. I enjoyed learning from topic-specific experts and learning about sexual and reproductive health issues in local, national, and international contexts.

This class was great overall. The course provides a great opportunity to gain a greater breath of knowledge with respect to past and current issues in sexual and reproductive health. The assigned readings were interesting and manageable. I appreciate that the instructor took the approach of inviting guest speakers to share their expertise and insight with us, with respect to certain topics. One weakness is that we often ran out of time to fully discuss topics or go more in depth on issues. Maybe there could be a greater emphasis on small group discussion among classmates in the future, rather than primarily listening to guest speakers.
She was good, however she did not teach much of the class. Her choice of guest speakers was phenomenal however

Strengths- content, guest speakers, passion of Professor
Weaknesses- would love to hear more from the professor

Prof. Cunningham was really great, she was very nice and always clear with her expectations for the course, etc. 
I echo my previous comment that I wish she had provided more instruction on the topic, rather than always relying on guest speakers.
Kind, thoughtful, approachable, warm. Knowledgable  - wish she had shared more about her research and particular areas of expertise. Would have liked to have learned more from her.
Shayna was a good teacher! She tried her very best to make this a great first semester for this class and I think it went well!

Professor Cunningham has been great! While there wasn't much chance to interact with her directly during the course (as guest lecturers spoke most of the time) she curated an interesting collection of readings and was clearly very knowledgeable about the material. She also kept us abreast of all of the relevant talks hosted by YSPH and the Medical School.

Shayna seems like a great and highly intelligent researcher. I was dismayed that not only did she not teach a single full lecture herself, she also spoke in a way that minimized her knowledge and accomplishments. She should try to work on speaking publicly in a confident manner, because she is clearly very capable and her diction patterns (saying "kind of" each sentence, repeating she is not an expert) minimize this.
Shayna was great - but we had guest speakers for all of the classes, so we were never really taught by Shayna.
already mentioned in my comment above
Good professor, wish she took more time to teach us content.
Dr. Cunningham described herself as the "curator" of this course. She invited many guest speakers throughout the semester but never really lectured.
She was a nice and interesting teacher, but I wish she taught the class more.

Very few lectures were taught by Dr. Cunningham but her class was good.  I thought it was a little unnecessary to have a weekly reading/writing assignment due the same day as our midterm, especially considering those readings were not discussed in class that day, but other than that, the work was fair.

Shayna was incredibly approachable and helpful whenever I interacted with her. Her passion for the subject shined though and she provided timely feedback. Overall, I really enjoyed having her as a professor and I am hoping to take another course with her during my YSPH experience.

Excellent. Very knowledgeable and approachable. Due to the nature of the class, she wasn't teaching as much as I would have liked (most of that was being done by community practitioners that were invited to the lecture). But when she did present, it was always interesting and professional. She was a great instructor overall and her class was innovative and interesting in its design and content.
I wish she lectured more! Course felt like a seminar with such a high volume of guest lectures.

15/10
Professor Cunningham was very enthusiastic, you could tell she really enjoyed teaching us and discussing our perspectives. She was incredibly kind and her tone really set the stage for the class. She's probably my favorite professor I've had at Yale.

Wonderful! She was a great and supportive instructor and brought in some amazing researchers/ professionals and challenged students to understand and evaluate many different facets of the public health challenges in the sexual/repro health space.
The instructor provided a safe environment to ask any question and discuss topics. She was motivating and caring to make the course a success.

YSPH would be an idiot not to offer Dr. Cunningham tenure.  Their biggest mistake would be to let her go.  I can't imagine this course without her and she's truly a trailblazer in the world of reproductive & sexual health.
Shayna was a very good teacher and did a very good job planning and running the course. She was good at leading discussion and offered up good insights.

The instructor of this course was great. She is knowledgeable, passionate, and knowledgeable about the course material. She also has a plethora of invaluable connections with the field that were excited to share their expertise with us, which was fantastic.

I think the class is an important one to have offered but would benefit from more expert guidance. Professor relied heavily on guest speakers to provide lectures, which was hit or miss. Oftentimes, it seemed like she was learning along with the rest of the class, as opposed to sharing her own expertise or perspective.
Dr. Cunningham was an amazing teacher and very supportive of the class. Her enthusiasm for the course was evident during each class session.

Professor Cunningham was excellent! She was kind, respectful, and responsive to student needs. She designed one of my favorite classes Ive taken at YSPH. I would have loved to hear even more about her professional experiences.
She's fantastic.  I love the way she provided the information for students and didn't force students to ever memorize the material.

Fantastic professor. Led difficult discussions very well. I am especially appreciative of how she honored how we felt during Kavanaugh hearings, which happened on a class day. No other professor took the time to do that, and I deeply appreciated it.
Dr. Cunningham was excellent in facilitating large group discussions and it was great that she invited a lot of different guest speakers to come in.

I appreciated the instructor's efforts to organize guests that covered a vast array of topics in the field of interest and to facilitate class discussion with these guest lecturers. The instructor's attention to events and lectures occurring outside of our classroom was also immensely beneficial to our engagement with the topic and our awareness of others at YSPH and beyond who share our interests.
Shes amazing. So easy to chat with and she knows so much information and is so passionate about the topic!

Professor Cunningham did a wonderful job leading and structuring the course. She was very approachable and definitely cared about our learning and opinion's of the course. I did wish that she spoke about her work and experiences a bit more.

Dr. Cunningham is a great instructor. She clearly put a lot of time and thought into creating the class schedule and arranging guest speakers. Her expectations for our short weekly essays, briefing report, and final project were clearly communicated and reasonable. I wish we had more opportunities to see Dr. Cunningham in action, directly teaching us as the lecturer for class. However, for the times in which Dr. Cunningham led the class, she was great and easily facilitated discussion.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student! I learned a lot.
Very interesting course, would recommend taking for the content and guest speakers. A reasonable time commitment with an interesting final project.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student interested in a broad coverage of sexual and reproductive health topics
Great class, especially if you have minimal background in the topic areas and would like a broad, introductory overview. Shayna is also lovely!

I think that this is a good class, and in time could be a great class. I think that some of the speakers could be adjusted, and that time should specifically be carved out to focus on some of the readings, or else not assign them. I also think that the final project could be mini-presentations, each for like 5 minutes, as opposed to walking around the class.

This is a pretty relaxed class in which much of the learning seems to be for one's own interest. There is not much way we are held accountable for the material each week, other than a short reading response. But it's an interesting way to explore reproductive healthcare in a way that is more practical than many of my more theoretical classes.
Great course, a lot of reading
Good class for anyone who already has a background or interest in sexual and reproductive health.
The readings for this class were the best part. The guest lectures were sometimes extremely rudimentary and mostly scratched the surface of very complex topics. The work load was extremely light.
Great topics, and workload is not bad. I enjoyed this class overall.

Have some cool guest speakers / experts on topics in sex/repro health, but be prepared for some busy work.  It is not difficult, but can often seem like an assignment just for the sake of giving weekly assignments.  Would be more worthwhile if the readings were actually discussed in class.  Great to take if you are interested in these topics, but may not be your best option if you feel less comfortable voicing an opinion on these topics in front of peers and experts.

Broad overview of sexual and reproductive health and reproductive justice movement. These themes/histories were relayed through a series of discussions with local practitioners and public health experts who visited our class weekly. The class only met once per week.

This course is a little bit of everything you wanted to know about reproductive health. A lot of topics get covered, but they're all very different from each other and provide some great nuanced points for discussion. The projects and class work are enjoyable and honestly, it'll be the highlight of your day. I would take it again. Professor Cunningham is amazing and she always gets great speakers who are very interesting to listen to.
The course provided a good mix of topics within sexual and reproductive health.
TAKE IT! TAKE IT!  TAKE IT!!!!

I would highly recommend this course. It provided a wide overview of various topics in sexual and reproductive health. While there were some subpar speakers, most were extremely knowledgeable and open to questions. The discussions were the best part of the class and the reading were very interesting.

This course is a wonderful survey course of sexual and reproductive health topics. This is a great class for those looking to learn more in the subject matter, who currently have little knowledge, as well as those who are already very knowledgeable. With discussion, copious diverse readings, and classes filled with guest speakers who are very knowledgeable about their niche in sexual and reproductive health, you will learn something new every class. I would highly recommend this class to everyone! Issues in sexual and reproductive health are relevant to anyone, no matter what aspect of the health field you plan to enter.
Was first time class was taught...an important course and topic but the class itself needs more work to be a truly comprehensive introduction into sexual and repro health.
I would recommend this course to any student looking to gain an understanding of the social and medical factors influencing sexual and reproductive health in the US.
It is mostly like a seminar. Almost every week there are guest speakers which kept it interesting and timely!
I highly recommend it. If you're looking for a class that isn't a TON of work but you still learn a lot, I definitely suggest taking the class.
Highly, highly recommend. Should definitely be offered again.

I think this is a great course to get an overview of main issues and topics concerning sexual health; I would recommend it to students interested in the general area but not sure about a specific topic of interest, who want to get a broad vision.
I would highly recommend this course to another student!

This course involved the input of leaders and experts inter field on many different topics surrounding sexual and reproductive health. I would highly recommend this course to other students who are interested in a holistic and comprehensive review of concepts surrounding the course's topic of interest.
Its engaging and interesting and you will enjoy going to class! I would highly recommend it!

This course is essential for anyone interested in sexual/reproductive health. The array of topics that are covered appeals to a variety of interests and a lot can be learned from the readings/lectures/assignments.
Great class! Highly recommend if interested in gaining a breadth of knowledge in sexual and reproductive health issues.
